extent.value: in 2 manuscript boxes and 1 half manuscript box

abstract.value: This collection is comprised of documents produced by and about Harry Turner (1919-1997), a Trotskyist, and member of the Socialist Workers Party (1964-66), who helped establish the Spartacist League. The collection contains published and unpublished writings by Turner inclusive of newspaper articles, pamphlets, statements, newsletters, and circular letters.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Harry Turner Papers; TAM 208; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

There is no documentation concerning the provenance of the original donation in this collection; the accession number associated with these materials is 1998.014. In October 2019, an accretion was donated by Jon Willinger. The accession number associated with the October 2019 accretion is 2019.124.

Harry Turner (1919-1997), born in Brooklyn, N.Y., joined the Communist Party in the 1930s, left in the aftermath of the Soviet suppression of the Hungarian Revolution of 1956, became a Trotskyist, and was a member of the Socialist Workers Party (1964-66), then helped establish the Spartacist League, but left it in 1968, then participated in various U.S. and international Trotskyist organizations until his death. Turner was also a rehabilitation counseler, working for the New York State Office of Vocationa Rehabilitation, and an activist in the New York State Civil Service Employees Association. A detailed listing of Turner's writings is available at the Library.

The collection contains published and unpublished writings by Turner -- newspaper articles, pamphlets, statements, newsletters, and circular letters -- the latter two often relating to the many Trotskyist organizations in which he participated.
